Title: Does being an indie gamedev actually pay the bills?
Body:
I mean, obviously, it depends on what you by "indie" but given what young people on web forums etc. usually mean by "indie" -- i.e. them and their friends putting something together without any external support -- the answer to the question, generally speaking, is no.

It is hard to make money off of a game project even if you successfully complete it. Let's put it this way: it is hard to finish a game, period. It is hard to start your project and somehow come up with the art and write all the code and actually finish it and get it up on the web or in an app store, etc. -- doing so is a real accomplishment if the game is at all non-trivial. Most teams never even make it to the point at which anything is playable much less polished and complete.

Howevever, that said, all things being equal, in terms of paying one's bill the above is far and a way the easy part. Implementation is easy because one can do it if one knows how and one sets one's mind to it and powers through. You can't set your mind to and power through gaining users and getting money, however. If you could every decent programmer in the world would be supporting themselves by writing independent games.

Title: What is being done to make gamedev work easier?
Body:
Aside from general ongoing improvements in technology, the Internet and the growing corpus of industry knowledge and experience: middleware/tooling and digital distribution.

Tools like Unity and its Asset Store, not to mention Unreal/CryEngine are a massive boost to indie/low-budget game dev. The barrier to entry and the learning curve has dropped greatly at the bottom end.

At the other end of the scale, those engines plus myriad tools like PathEngine, ScaleForm, Havok, etc help folks get things done (not to say that AAA game projects have gotten cheaper or easier, they certainly haven't, but a great deal more can be achieved).

The digital distribution thing may not technically be part of the "development" bit, but platforms like Steam (with its Early Access and Greenlight programs) and the huge rise of mobile app stores have greatly enhanced the scope of indie/low-budget game devs. Getting your stuff in reach of the average consumer is entirely doable nowadays (getting them to buy it is another story), as is making sure they have a reasonable chance of installing your latest patches and updates, and flogging them more content via DLC and in-app purchases. Years ago selling your games was a closed shop (ho ho) reserved for big publishers working through largely inaccessible retail markets.

Those same big publishers can also use Steam and app stores to push smaller products out faster, invest in more experimental things that would have been too risky before, avoid physical distribution hassles, keep everyone updated, sell DLC, manage piracy, etc.

Title: Why are so many gamedevs willing to work at such long hours for low pay?
Body:
I've never worked professionally as a game developer, but I've seriously considered working towards it as a career path on many occasions and I assume that some of my motivations are shared by actual professional game devs.

There's an undeniable "cool" factor in getting to program games, especially on next-generation AAA titles. Game programmers get to push technology to its absolute limits for the sheer purpose of spreading joy and blowing minds. A typical AAA game involves the implementation of physics, advanced mathematics, cutting edge graphics, artificial intelligence, networking techniques/algorithms (if it is a multiplayer game), and tons of other fascinating topics. When comparing this to your typical enterprise software, the latter can seem depressingly trivial and mundane.

Personally, the sweet spot for me is working in a software/web-dev job where I get to work on projects that interest me (though perhaps not as much as games interest me), make good money, and work reasonable hours. I still get to pursue my game dev interests and learn lots of cool things in my free time by working on my own indie game projects, but I also get to be comfortable and well-paid and not be exploited.

Fortunately for game developers, the impression I have is that their skillset is generally a superset of what is required to succeed in more generalized software development. Game developers not only have to have strong general programming/algorithmic skills, but also often need to have a very deep understanding in one or more specific aspects of game dev (such as graphics, AI, etc). So I imagine that a game developer who wants to transition to non-game development wouldn't have too much trouble.
